headline: Do you really want to play for the New York Jets?
pros: Flexible PTO policy. Quarterly stipend to spend on the platform. Health care coverage is great and maternity/paternity leave is competitive with other tech companies. Benefits are the only thing making me give the company 2 stars as opposed to 1 in this review.
cons:
You'll see several reviews left in early 2020 from disgruntled employees that were laid off due to COVID. While it may seem easy to dismiss those reviews given the circumstances, but let me give you a review from an employee that spent several years at Thumbtack and survived COVID layoffs. You'll see that the feedback given by those employees that were laid off is valid feedback and should be taken into consideration when deciding what kind of company you'd like to work for. I'll keep this as short as possible but I think every potential hire has the right to hear what it's really like working at Thumbtack.

I'll start off by saying that every month or so Thumbtack sends out a survey to employees and one of the questions is, "would you recommend Thumbtack to a friend?" For at least the last year my answer has consistently been "no". If "strong no" was an option then that's what I would be selecting.

Thumbtack doesn't care about your career growth. You're simply a cog in their machine. There is a total lack of career mapping and leadership never discussed growth opportunities with me despite asking to have the conversation many many times. If you ever decide you want to move on from Thumbtack you will be replaced by another cog that is less qualified and will do your job for less money since Thumbtack doesn't like going out and backfilling positions externally--they will find someone internally that can fill the gap. They very much operate with a "next up" mindset. They then underpay those employees because they have less experience or are less qualified but fully expect them to carry out the responsibilities of those employees that have left. Despite how long you've worked there, you can very well expect a "don't let the door hit you on the way out" attitude from the company if you decide to leave.

The product team operates in their own bubble in San Francisco and regularly pushes out product updates with no warning or education regarding the updates being rolled out. This leaves support and success teams floundering when discussing product changes with Thumbtack customers and businesses on the platform.

The sales team is a runaway train at this point. Thumbtack will do everything necessary to continue growing the sales team and they will provide whatever is necessary to scale and grow that team. If you're expecting internal support then be ready to fight sales for resources since they are priority #1.

There is a revolving door of leadership at Thumbtack. Leaders come in and often don't stick around long when they figure out how things are run at Thumbtack. Expect change often as you'll likely have new leaders regularly. In my experience, leadership is also extremely out of touch with what is going on with their respective teams. They are so underwater with outstanding tasks or projects that limited support and unfulfilled promises are very much the norm.

I'll wrap this up with an analogy: if you're a top draft pick in the NFL draft and you really want to win a Super Bowl, do you really want to be drafted by the New York Jets? You'll only go so far with a poor coach, bad ownership, and a lack of a gameplan. Plus, good luck getting another team to look at you if you hang around long--being the best player on the New York Jets isn't necessarily impressive.

Now cue the Thumbtack damage control team with a standardized statement about how they are grateful for my time at Thumbtack (or at least I'm hoping they respond since no one ever thanked me after several years working for the company).

Leadership, specifically Marco. headline: Thumbtack Review - creative, huh?
pros:
I have been at Thumbtack for less than 1 year (similar to many other TT-ers). I have never been to the office, but I hear there was an amazing culture pre-Covid. The company is pretty spread out already with teams in SF, Salt Lake City, Toronto, and the Philippines. 

Based on hiring since Covid started, I would be surprised to see a strong move to have everyone back in an office post covid. Though, I do think that there will still be a majority of employees working a reasonable amount of time in an office with exceptions for roles that can largely be done remotely (engineering comes to mind). There have been leadership role hires outside the Bay, which seems to have been rare (non-existent) pre-Covid. 

This year was a rollercoaster for the company, but luckily things seem to be looking good going into the end of the year. People are optimistic about the future, and there are a lot of new, strong ICs and Leaders that joined to help continue the current momentum into the new year and beyond.

Pros:
- Overall the people at Thumbtack are smart and kind.
- The people team really does try to create an awesome culture (even while working remotely).
- Leadership at the highest levels seems aligned and focused, with clear goals in mind.
- There is a lot of freedom to try things and experiment, as well as own your area of the product.
- TT Bucks, Internet, Phone Reimbursement, Good comp
- Remote events show that the people at TT also have skills outside of work (singers, poets, chefs, athletes, overall musicians - people are crazy talented)
- The work on my team is interesting, the problems are hard, and the data are actually quite clean (not the dumpster fire of most companies) - so the opportunities are large.
cons:
Cons:
- There are a lot of new people, and (like a lot of other startups) also reasonably high attrition, which can make it hard to move in an aligned direction and know where everything is to help move together. Some TT-ers seem to still be holding hard feelings from layoffs earlier this year.
- There are a lot of things that aren't figured out or haven't been built that you might expect a company that has been around for 12 years to have already figured out. Why this is the case - could be related to attrition - there is a lot of poaching of TT talent, but I am truly not sure. Could be that the problems are hard - yea, they are, but I don't totally buy that... 
- Note: Many of these projects seem to be on the roadmap, but from my observation, short-term wins often seem to take priority over these lengthy investments. In the remote world, my view isn't super far into what other teams are working on.
- I have been here almost a year and have not once had a talk about growth or a performance review from my manager. Potentially folks being overlooked due to not having these conversations also leads to attrition? 
- No 401k match

headline: How not to handle COVID layoffs
pros: Many before COVID, none now.
cons:
The leadership team decided to lay off 250+ employees right at the beginning of the pandemic (late March 2020). We were all given 3.5 weeks severance pay, regardless of tenure or level. All 250 of us were told that our jobs had been eliminated on a pre-recorded 3min Zoom call with the CEO. Immediately after the Zoom call ended, our laptops were shutdown remotely. We later were instructed to ship the laptops back to HQ and that was it. 

This was a truly cold and heartless decision that was ultimately unnecessary. It was handled sloppily and executed with callousness and ambivalence. 

The most egregious actions came immediately after they layoffs. A large number of employees on the people ops team were promoted and likely received comp increases. The people charged with leading this braindead layoff process were then immediately rewarded with promotions. What a joke. Extremely disappointing.

headline: Great place to work!
pros:
I started working at Thumbtack right out of college, and I couldn't think of a better place to kick-start my career. I still can't believe that I get to work for such an amazing company and do what I love every single day!

It was really important to me that I found a company that actually lived their values, and I can confidently say that Thumbtack does. Our values are at the foundation of everything we do. 

Something else I really appreciate is how open and honest our senior leadership team is. It's not common to work for a company that is so transparent, so it's very refreshing.

Thumbtack really cares about their employees, especially through the pandemic that we're facing. They've given us extra paid holidays to support our mental health. They also hold workshops to learn more about mental health, healthy habits for working from home, empowering women, and so much more. They even have fun yoga classes taught by a Thumbtack pro, which is my personal favorite! This is just a small glimpse of the benefits you get for working here.

Overall, I love Thumbtack. I can't wait to see how much I will grow by working here!
cons: As of now, I haven't seen any cons of working for Thumbtack.

And the leadership team only took advice from the lead analyst. If you are not the lead analyst, your job is not impactful. You are also under the pressure to make data look like what stakeholders want. If not, people will say you are not clear about what the goal is on your performance review.

headline: Unless you are planning to work in SF, stay away!
pros: Generous PTO. Good medical, paternity, maternity benefits. Some of the staff who believe in a transparent, collaborative, employee and customer focused workplace are still employed. Fair compensation. Condones work life balance. Flexible work from home even before the pandemic. Health and safety of employees are a priority.
cons:
No longer customer focused. Sales is pushing increased revenue, but Thumbtack is purposely employing so little staff that customers wait excessive amounts of time for issues to be addressed.
Older female employees do not last long here. The majority of women in senior leadership older than 40 has been pushed out or laid off by the "moral compass". Anyone with the audacity to disagree with People Ops becomes a target.
Marco condones individuals in People Ops who bully, make derogatory comments publicly about employees, and have extreme integrity issues; even calling them the company's "moral compass" . All escalations of inappropriate behavior in People Ops have been brushed off possibly not even looked into. Disciplinary action is not equitable. Someone can steal thousands of dollars and still be employed while someone else will be terminated for far less.
Customer support is no longer a collaborative entity. One person controls all meetings. One person speaks through the majority of these meetings. Managers were even told to stop having one on one meetings with each other.
Planning used to be a collaborative process with employees on several levels providing ideas and input. Now one person creates all planning initiatives and dictates them to the team. Input from anyone at a "level" beneath Director level is routinely ignored. Titles are more important than actual knowledge.
Turnover has increased exponentially in Salt Lake. The atmosphere is now that of a typical outsourcing call center. Constant back to back contacts with no end in sight.
The hierarchy of San Francisco as most important, Salt Lake as 2nd class, and Philippines as 3rd class employees has returned.

headline: High Integrity, Fairness and Good People
pros:
I have worked at TT for several years and I cannot say enough good things about it. The executive team (this includes execs recently called out in a negative light on GD) has high integrity and they are more transparent with their employees than any other employer I have worked for. I believe the reviews in disagreement with this sentiment haven't worked for very many other companies and have a very limited view of the world. 
The company works hard to provide its employees with incredible benefits and perks. There are development opportunities (which come in different ways than simply climbing the ladder) for those who are driven and passionate about their work. One area that they are really doubling down on recently is building flexibility and support in a remote environment. They are rolling out a remote work support fund to assist in the cost of family care (child care, elder care, tutoring) and continuing education options. As a working parent, I am so very grateful for the flexibility that allows me to bring my whole self to work and also help my child with online school this year. 
The business is doing very well! They have hired and promoted people into leadership roles who are having an incredible impact early and it is showing in the business performance. This is incredible given the uncertain times we are in and yes, we did have a layoff but I will say that I admired the fact that the execs took action quickly. It was a very hard thing to do but necessary given the circumstances. I have worked in other start-ups that waited beyond the point of no return.
cons: It is a very analytical company and there are times when they get absorbed in the data rather than acting. This slows us down but even that has been improving over the last year.

headline: Perform at your best and you still get shafted
pros: Free food. Thats the only positive thing I can say.

During the fall of last year they started hiring so many new sales representatives. We were all concerend they were growing too quickly. They assured us they weren't even though we all knew it wasn't a good idea. Then they started firing people left and right. Then COVID struck. My team had the best sales out of all of the other teams and almost every single one of us had a PR in sales. My whole team but 2 people were laid off. Explain to me why the best sales team from March would be the ones chosen to lay-off? Under all of the pressure of the first month of quarantine and working from home, cut the only team that made record sales and worked the hardest? Not logical but thanks Marco. I can't even begin to talk about how emotionless Marco was when laying off his employees. It was a Zoom call and then immediatly after, our laptops shut off. We couldn't say bye to anyone, didnt know who else was laid off, was not sure what was going to happen next... So inhumane, so disgusting. I tell everyone I know to never go near Thumbtack if you are looking for a job. They make you think they care by giving you free food but when push comes to shove, they don't care about you :) so find somewhere better, trust me, it is easy to do. Try Mcdonalds. Im sure you'll get free food there and some more respect.

headline: Failed Leadership and Lack of Oversight or Control
pros: Thumbtack faces interesting challenges as a marketplace with the goal of providing immediate feedback to users. The company is at a scale where there are serious problems to tackle on the product, BI, and technical sides of the company.
cons: Leadership is poor and has a high turnover rate. Management does not care for their reports and ICs are left to fend for themselves. Decisions are made based on who speaks the loudest, defaulting to whoever has the highest level. ICs have little input in what they work on and sometimes boil down to little more than highly-paid contractors instead of software engineers. This leads to an overall culture where engineering holds the product hostage and blocks (purposefully or otherwise) the implementation of new features.

headline: Thumbtack used to be a great place to work in customer support. Now? Avoid at all costs.
pros: Thumbtack had a unique culture with a startup mentality where people come first. At one time, CS agents had the autonomy to "do the right thing," and go out of their way to make sure we were giving the best assistance possible. Our role was to help the users of our site succeed and understand how to make the most of the product.
cons: There was a drastic decline in culture and the embodiment of company values in Customer Support when the new CS director took over in 2019. It became like any other soul-crushing call center job. We were consistently understaffed, which was intentional to save money, but extremely stressful and draining to CS agents. The call volume was relentless, and we were encouraged to be less helpful so that calls would be shorter.  Our users seemed to be increasingly losing faith in us, as customer support is the face of Thumbtack. The attendance policy was changed to require everyone to work despite previously planned vacation, etc. if an especially busy day was forecasted. We lost all the great perks and benefits that set Thumbtack apart from other companies.

So much information, yet almost no time to learn it, felt unprepared by management and company to perform my job.

headline: Incompetent Leadership, Hypocritical Culture -> Ship is Sinking
pros:
- When times were good pre-2020, Thumbtack cultivated a culture of transparency, humility, and work-life balance.
- All my managers for the most part prioritized my professional development and supported me to do my job in a fulfilling way. 
- Most of my coworkers were a pleasure to work with. There wasn't as much politics as other companies at my level due to some good operating processes set up.
- The onsite meals were great and the culinary team was world-class.
cons:
But a company's true character shows when times are tough, and Thumbtack completely failed the test. In a founder-CEO company, the true color of company morals is usually a manifestation of the character of the CEO, and I am extremely disappointed how Marco handled the last few months. While Marco had issues pre-pandemic (most prominently, his inability to put together a good executive team and broker cohesion amongst them), I still believed that his overall capability and moral compass would guide Thumbtack through ups and downs. I was wrong:

- The covid layoff was a disaster and you can read more about it in the previous reviews. 3 months later both former and current employees are still reeling. Go compare how you handled the layoff to how Brian Chesky handled the Airbnb layoff, night and day difference. Just go read Airbnb's Glassdoor reviews around the same time frame and you will see laid off employees not nearly as scarred.

- The icing on the cake is laying off the entire DEI team. Then when BLM protests happened, trying to claim in a public blog post diversity and inclusion is top priority and that they would prioritize hiring DEI folks, without mentioning that they actually laid off the entire DEI team just a couple months ago. Utter hypocrisy.

- A lot of the executive team are not qualified. They can't get along with each other. And they keep leaving or keep getting fired. This again illustrates the incompetence of the CEO:
 -> 4 CPOs over a few years with the last one getting straight up laid off. I think Marco doesn't know how to have a CPO and needs full control over the product.
 -> No one on the executive team has stayed for more than 3-4 years. The last few years saw complete turnover of the exec team. The current CTO, who's actually qualified, just quit.
 -> Unqualified people keep getting put onto the exec team. Just one example, the current head of Design has never worked as a Product Designer, but rather a User Researcher and was in school only a few year ago.

headline: It's falling apart
pros: We're getting paid still and our benefits haven't been completely cut yet, I guess that's good.
cons: There's an idea that Thumbtack is doing good work, building a platform for working-class people to find work especially in times like today. Even though the company wasn't profitable before, it's weird that we laid off over 200 employees and now we're being told things are looking good, even better than ever. Also, our CTO just quit, claiming it was time to take a break and maybe that's true, but who knows. Many of us don't know what or who to believe anymore. The few people who have interviewed here in the last two months ask questions about our culture and we're told to focus on the positive but they can just read this page and see all the stories. And I just saw a negative review below had the wrong copy/paste template response as if the review was praising the team. Engineers are going to keep quitting here, it's been months since the layoffs and morale and culture continue to suffer. I read a story that they tried to hire back our old head of diversity after laying him off not too long ago. Who would've thought that was a good idea? These are such "senior" leaders and they don't know the rule of burning bridges?

They said it was because of COVID-19, but that was a lie. Work here if you feel like swimming in a shark tank where leaders are left to fight each other for position and authority.

headline: Went Downhill
pros: The catered lunches, generous PTO policy, and great benefits. Thumbtack used to have a wonderful culture, where actions matched company values, employees were genuinely appreciated, and decisions were made in the best interest of the small businesses and employees. I had the opportunity to work with a lot of intelligent and hardworking people that drove me perform highly and learn new skills.
cons:
Culture shifted to one that includes a lack of transparency, poor management, actions of leadership don't align with company values. Thumbtack also does a really poor job of implementing feedback from the small businesses that rely on them. It became very clear that revenue is the only driver of decisions at Thumbtack, probably due to the amount funding from Sequoia Capital; I'd imagine they're very concerned about their ROI. 

The lack of loyalty to employees also really stands out, Thumbtack let go off many tenured, loyal, and high performing employees due to Covid.

Head of Diversity & Inclusion and many ERG leads were let go as well, but due to current events Thumbtack is claiming D&I is a priority. Just one example of Thumbtack talking the talk but not walking the walk.

headline: It's gone from bad to worse...
pros: I am not sure I can really list out a pro for Thumbtack anymore. The only pro I can give is that, they gave us a definitive timeframe that is far out into the future for work from home so that we can plan our lives accordingly.
cons: When the layoffs happened things were pretty bad. A lot of people felt blindsided, but you can read more about that in the previous reviews. Our success organization in the last 6 months has made 3-4 significant changes at the detriment to the employees. Morale is incredibly low, and no one seems to really care. We hear a lot of "we're working on this", "we hear you", "your feedback matters". But we're going on 3 months of a really bad working environment and it's only getting worse by the day. We have managers who can't manage the amount of employees they now have underneath them, managers who are unable to make decisions and best of all managers who are unresponsive and non-communicative to their employees. Some teams went from 12-15 employees and are down to three, doing even more work and with less pay due to the layoff pay cuts. We communicate to management that we can’t take on anymore and we’re at capacity and all we get told is “I hear you”.  There seems to be no one who can even help anymore. Management and HR's version of help is "we hear you". Great, so what can we do about it. Thumbtack is going down a hole that I am not sure they will be able to dig themselves out of, specifically for this department. Majority of the team is looking for new opportunities, but at this point, I am not sure anyone cares.

headline: Toxic workplace, zero regard for D&I

headline: Stop masking the truth with culture
pros:
The team I worked with was phenomenal.
I learned so much while working here and decided my career path.
The culinary staff, the friendships, the WPX team, the awesome office, etc.
cons:
After a lot of reflection, I’m grateful for the knowledge I received while being at Thumbtack. That being said, I should be much further in my career than I am. They stunted my growth, they played favorites, and HR didn’t protect us. We weren’t paid to industry standards. 

Management, before I was laid off, was getting to a better point, but prior to that management was awful. They played favorites and had hidden agendas. They threw people under the bus, and sometime the people they threw got let go for “performance.” Many of the people in leadership positions should have NEVER been in leadership positions.

I was taken for granted, my skills were taken for granted, my entire team was taken for granted and it hurts me to my core. I gave you two stars because I love what Thumbtack is doing to help businesses. I will continue to use Thumbtack, but I do NOT recommend working for a company who has hidden agendas, who lacks transparency, and who lays off 250 employees without batting an eye. They gave us the assumption we’d be safe and that was unfair and unethical.

headline: Two-faced company towards new employees - Very Disappointed
pros:
- Workspace is very nice and chill, free lunch and snacks.
- Coworkers are friendly and willing to help.
- Initial learning opportunity is good for new employees. Until everything happened later, I was learning a lot about the company and the product and really enjoyed my work.
cons:
- Worst possible way to layoff 250 employees
It is understandable that many companies are suffering during this crisis and have to layoff employees. What differentiates a good company and a bad company is really how it handles the layoff. Thumbtack is definitely NOT good - hiding the decision and playing around with words on layoff-related questions during AllThumb meetings. The layoff meeting is literally 3-5 minutes with the CEO just reading a script saying it's your last day with a neutral face. Then laptops are immediately shut -> probably the fastest IT team during the layoff season. Ironically, revenue went up and almost back to normal just couple days after the layoff. Wondering how the decision is made? 

- Two-faced treatment
The team is very friendly and helps each other, creating a very good work environment before COVID hits in middle March. However, throughout the layoff, as mentioned in other reviews, the true color of this company is revealed. Like some other people, my manager never reached out to explain what happened, though showed signs of negligence days before the layoff.
Completely agrees with "One week after [layoff], promotions of the remaining employees started trickling in on linkedin. Downright UNETHICAL and INSENSITIVE while a number of us are still reeling from the job loss." I have to admit, it is heart-warming when seeing some coworkers I never worked with willing to help me during my job search. It is also disappointed that some people I regard as teammates are just so cold during this difficult time -> that's why I feel the company as a whole just has a culture of two-faced treatment when there's no longer any value/benefit to be extracted from you.

- Company values look good for outsiders, but that's it
The severance package is by far the WORST among tech companies, especially during this WORLDWIDE HEALTH CRISIS. Many people still need to feed their families and worry about the health of their families -> Thumbtack is definitely not considerate at all. Moreover, a month after the layoff, posts again appearing on LinkedIn suggesting this company is praised for providing support for wfh supplies. Remember a month ago it doesn't willing to provide better severance pay.

headline: Best Startup I Have Worked At Thus Far
pros:
Transparency. Stability. Knowledgeable and strategic leadership.

I have worked for six startups across the country. Startups are risky because you never really know the stability until you get in the office. I have been laid off four times from startup environments. 
The reason I joined Thumbtack is for the "recession proof" product. I did not want to be laid off again and felt the market was leaning that way when I joined. 

My managers and the founders were transparent in most avenues, more so than I have ever experienced. The first few weeks I was there I saw clear revenue reports, met everyone on the leadership team, and most of the directors that I would be reporting to. I had clear goals but the way to achieve those was left to me. I appreciate that I was given the opportunity to learn and flourish on my own while having a supportive team of managers behind me to help with any issues or questions I had.

As I continued with Thumbtack I felt trusted, relied on, and appreciated. That combined with the support I have received really opened my eyes to how offices could be run. I also enjoyed the whole team. Working in SF it is so easy to run into tech egos and complete lack of perspective (ie: privileged af) . Thumbtack was a breath of fresh air. All the big company perks with the big company jerks.
cons:
Post Covid Morale

Thumbtack saw its first lay off with the emergence of Covid-19. I will admit, the layoff process was cold but I understood from a business perspective. It is hard to ensure the safety of a company's networks and assets when saying goodbye to 250 people at the same time. But, it also had to protect those things to protect the 600 some odd employees remaining. My two cents, no one expected this lay off. Mistakes were made. It sucks. People are hurt. Perspective, Thumbtack did one big lay off in one solid move to ensure future runway and limit debt incursion. For those that are still there, I am glad they are with a company who thinks strategically and doesn't drop 30% of its staff more than once as we are seeing in other companies in this market.

headline: Lacking real leadership
pros:
Amazing food when we were in the office
Good work/life balance when in the office
cons:
- I didn't get laid off during the mass layoff but the way it was handled really upset many people including me and leadership never addressed head on why they were so heartless. It was a ton of platitudes and avoiding the real question. Just take a look at the copied and pasted responses to all the reviews to understand the type of stuff we hear weekly as questions are asked. There are things that need to be done to keep a business alive, but there are more humane ways to do it (literally any other way would have been better). 
- Performance across teams and offices are uneven, which comes across as unfair, making it difficult to get promoted. Leaders don't even seem aware of the numerous people issues or at least they don't care about them. 
- The culture seems to really vary based on the team you are on and if you end up on the wrong team then it's difficult to move up because of the inconsistencies stated above.
- Leadership and management in general can never seem to take ownership of mistakes they've made or continue to make which makes it difficult to give meaningful feedback without fear of repercussions. This is even harder because feedback is not anonymous.
- Benefits have deteriorated in the past year including pay cuts

headline: All good things must come to an end!
pros: The culinary staff and ERG Leaders. Unfortunately all laid off.
cons: Unfortunately all good things must come to an end, and that is the case for Thumbtack's culture and employee morale. Once a thriving employer has seen it's business decisions both internally and externally cause massive waves of attrition across multiple departments (this is well documented) and in masses in 2018 and 2019. 2020 saw Covid layoffs of 250 employees a mere 2 weeks into lockdown (Huge cash issue signal) including many ERG Leads, and all Diversity staff. Struggling to find CPO and CFO. Valuation is barely beating inflation over past 4 years. The work is meaningful but the culture is completely shot unfortunately. Many left there after layoffs are actively interviewing.

headline: Worst place for mid-senior people to grow
pros:
Robust infrastructure to support new product launches
Detailed documentations for new hires to get hands on quickly
cons:
*Worst place for mid-senior people to grow*
Thumbtack is great for new grads to learn and grow but not for mid-senior people. Overall, Thumbtack SUFFERS FROM HIRING SENIOR PEOPLE for all teams. 75% of my teams was at my level. 25% was below me. There were no seniors above my level except my manager. Managers spent more time on managing up and judging you based on limited knowledge. You would think you could learn from XFN teams but after just a few months, half of the senior people from XFM teams left. What a coincidence!

*Unfair evaluation + non-competitive pay*
The 360 performance review was completely unfair. Managers ignored XFN teams say about you and made ratings based on pre-judgement. There were no salary raise + no bonus + no 401k match. I would SUGGEST incoming new hires NEGOTIATE YOUR BASE SALARY AS MUCH AS YOU CAN. Because you had no chance to raise your pay unless getting promoted. That’s another reason why the average tenure at Thumbtack is less than 2 years. 

*How Thumbtack lose top talents during layoff*
5-minutes Zoom layoff message from our CEO Marco marked the ending of ~250 employees life with Thumbtack. Everyone understood the difficult times Thumbtack went through. However, the 250 employees had no individual 1:1 with their HR partner or senior leaders to know specific reasons but forcing to face a lockout screen in front of them. This poorly handled layoff message not only made the talents you laid off NEVER WANT TO CONSIDER THUMBTACK AGAIN but also give survivors a big cue to start to look for new opportunities ASAP. Oh forgot to say, the revenue went up in 10 days since the layoff. Are we really running out of the $150m money received 9 months ago?

*Less feeling like a family”
After laying off, my team never hosted a goodbye party for us. My manager also didn’t call me to explain what has happened. Totally echo the comment below
“Thumbtack laid off ~250 employees as a result of the covid pandemic. One week after, promotions of the remaining employees started trickling in on linkedin. Downright UNETHICAL and INSENSITIVE while a number of us are still reeling from the job loss.”

Goodbye Thumbtack. Good luck!

headline: The most disappointing end possible.
pros:
The in-house culinary team (though they were laid off)
The in-house employee resource group leads (though they were laid off)
cons: Unfortunately, Thumbtack laid off about 250 people. Yes, that’s happening everywhere and it was a necessary business decision, but the way it was delivered was not good. Employees were left scrambling to call their managers and peers trying to figure out what next steps were after being let go. Computers were shut off within minutes (we weren’t told they would be cutoff so quickly, no time for goodbyes) and we barely got 3 weeks of pay and about 4 weeks of health insurance. So many teams, and we’re given absolutely zero details on who they decided to cut. Even executives and long-tenured employees CHOSE to leave alongside those layed-off. I’m not even sure if there’s a recruiting team there anymore but I imagine Thumbtack is no longer a “best workplace”.

headline: I thought it was great until things started to surface
pros: Great food and healthy snacks.
cons:
Thumbtack laid off ~250 employees as a result of the covid pandemic. One week after, promotions of the remaining employees started trickling in on linkedin. Downright UNETHICAL and INSENSITIVE while a number of us are still reeling from the job loss.

Messaging was poorly handled at the time of the layoff with Marco reading a script that it would be our last day.  Poor severance pay. Your true character is revealed in this especially tough time and Thumbtack just showed that. 

VP of People at least reached out with a personal email.

Lack of trust from management. Recruiter-Sourcer partnership was more of Manager-subordinate relationship. Sourcers are treated like some adopted children at this company.

headline: Avoid Thumbtack If You are a Doer
pros: I loved my team and my manager to death. It was a team of great people who really tried to help me grow. I was fortunate to work with them and they became some of my best friends in SF. The tech infrastructure is also decent. When I do analysis seldomly would I face blockers from data infra. I also like the accessibility of information. You can learn what other teams are doing easily from reading their decks and dashboards.
cons:
(I’m biased because I was impacted by the COVID layoff)
The leadership promoted some of the worst culture a tech company could have. First, Thumbtack culture had stifled innovation in favor of predictability and forecast. If you interview, ask them if they can name one big innovation Thumbtack had succeeded in the past year. Second, the leadership is more a politician who cared about appearance more than execution. Not only would it would never admit to strategic failures, it celebrated the silver linings as success. Third, instead of defending the truth, the business analysts were forced to hack analysis to deliberately confirm the result leadership wants to see, and those numbers were used to set company annual planning. Lastly, the leadership is a hypocrite. They will tell you how they cared about employees by doing PC things like paternity leaves, while laying off 30% people without any performance based review.

headline: Pro Success Specialist

You get catered lunches Mon-Fri which save a ton of money especially since they are great caterers that make the food fresh every day,  kombucha on tap, and tons of snacks to munch on. There is a gym to use, and tons of events to break up the monotony of the work week. Culture is everything here! Oh and you get "Thumbtack bucks" to use quarterly which can save you a lot of money on your personal projects you'd use the site for on your own.
cons: Constant changes with teams and the product itself, this can be good or bad depending on how you like a changing environment. For me I don't mind but I know some people have a hard time with it. There is not as much room for growth as I would like, it seems a lot of people when they get to where I am at have left for other companies after applying for multiple positions here and not getting them. There has been talk of getting a bonus structure built out for quite a while, but nothing put in place yet and it's been over a year. Honestly, I love the culture but other jobs do seem tempting that have a more competitive compensation for similar roles.

headline: Management Changes Killed The Culture
pros: Thumbtack offers a lot of perks and benefits, including a generous PTO policy, laptops for work and personal use, free lunches, tons of snacks, coffee machines, fun company events, etc. The company vision is something that I believed in from day one, and still do. They want small businesses to grow and succeed. It shows, especially when you visit the San Francisco office. There's a lot of energy behind that vision.
cons:
In the Salt Lake office, the culture was once laid-back, fun, and amazing. At the time I started working there, it was hands-down the best place to work in Utah. People were promoted based on hard work and drive. Employees constantly went above and beyond because at that time, you were recognized for doing so.

Now, however, the Salt Lake office has become riddled with political agendas and favoritism. Managers that were once friendly with their employees became bosses, pushing numbers instead of empowering people. People get promoted based on their friendships outside of work with their managers, rather than their actual achievements. (For example: The people who go out drinking with the boss are the ones that get the most attention, rather than the ones that keep their heads down.) You can have the exact same metrics as someone else, but they'll get promoted over you because they're sucking up and you're not. This never, EVER used to be allowed at Thumbtack (most managers would be annoyed with the teacher's pet kind of employee), but now it's the norm.

Many departments are weighed down by stressful goals and ridiculous, impossible performance plans that only set people up to fail. There are multiple managers in multiple departments that aren't people leaders and don't know how to be. Those managers in particular are a HUGE part of what has destroyed the culture and have pushed people to their limit. 

Surprisingly for a company that's growing rapidly, there's little to no opportunity for growth in many departments there. The only hope you have for moving up is starting in customer support. However, once you're out of that department, good luck going anywhere else. 

The Salt Lake office is also riddled with HR red flags, but it's virtually impossible to go to HR without getting in trouble for it. Multiple managers and "star" employees are walking HR violations, but continue to be rewarded rather than punished for their behavior. 

Overall, Thumbtack WAS an amazing place to work but now the culture is stressful, toxic, and severely overrated.

headline: Without a doubt the best place I've ever worked at.
pros:
-Inclusive Culture

The culture here is excellent, it really feels like family when coming here, which is a good thing since we spend most of our days with our co-workers. Cross department communication is great as well.

-Room for Growth

Internal mobility is encouraged here, as well as opportunities to be a mentor or mentee with another Thumbtacker. 

-Seamless Onboarding

This really gets started about a week before you get here, you get to pick your own equipment and desk setup before you even get here. When you do get here all of your stuff is ready to go at your desk, including a sweet little welcome package. Extended onboarding includes Thumbtack University which is a multi-day training session that goes over the company and its history. The product’s evolution and current state, and some research methods and options within Thumbtack. 

-Food

The food here is ridiculously good. Food here is cooked in house by some of the most amazing chefs. You’ll be enjoying daily breakfast, lunch, and dinner (except Fridays). Also with Thursday snack days you’ll be treated to an assortment of in house snacks and beverages. Speaking of beverages there are ‘coolers’ or ‘refreshers’ made in house, a personal favorite is the Passion Fruit cooler. We also have a few beers and wines on tap, and in cans/bottles if you don’t like those options. There’s even an instagram account dedicated to this talented crews’ work. 

-Extremely flexible with PTO

Need time off? Take it.

-Transparency

Meeting notes are dispersed across departments which provides a window on what the company is working on. This goes all the way to the top.

-Thoughtful and Hands on Leadership

Leadership here is astoundingly great and active! They’re quick to respond to major events and set a great atmosphere for the company as a whole. They listen to feedback 
	
-Offsite Team Building Events

Want to get to know your team better? Don’t worry you’ll have a lot of opportunities to get out of the office with your team and build that relationship up!

-On-site Guest Speaker Events

Thumbtack is increasing their efforts in being thought leaders and having more community based events. 

-Community Involvement 

Thumbtackers respond to help out our local community, especially when they need it most like our most recent fires. We also have a few internal groups for different sports and activities that take place outside of work hours.	

-SF Office Space / Location 

We’re in the Twitter building which is pretty convenient for most people living in the city, and pretty close to most transportation options.
cons: It's hard to write something here without sounding pretentious and entitled. I don't have any complaints.

headline: Unique Culture & Start-up with Real Potential
pros:
I have worked in many start-ups in my career and this is the first one with incredible potential.  The executive team is engaged in the success of the business and with its employees. We are shifting the product and the culture to drive better outcomes for our pros, customers, and employees.
Thumbtack is great to its employees. They are very transparent with how the company is doing, the company goals, soliciting feedback from employees, leadership is very approachable to all.
cons:
Things have been really laid back and at times it is hard to drive accountability. The good news is the leadership team recognizes this and is making changes to address this.
There are growing pains for sure but nothing that cannot be worked through.

headline: The outside is appealing, that's how they get you
pros:
Free food.
Decent working hours.
Specific teams aren't bad.
The benefits are great.
cons:
Faking it completely. The CEO came to Salt Lake to deliver news and decided to plant people in the audience to say kind things about the updates to shape the narrative. If that isn't shady, I don't know what is. 
The politicking is insane.
The "culture" isn't diverse. Hiring the same type of people doesn't get you new ideas or thinking outside of the box. Getting actually diversity in people instead of who they voted for would do you good. It's a fancy call center for lazy hipsters.
The CEO and leadership think they are bigger than they are and walk around with their noses in the air. They company is still growing and it's a good time to be humble.
There wasn't an HR until the last year or so. Lots of issues brewing that aren't being solved. People get promoted to leadership because of who they know, not because of their work ethic. Overpaid management and underpaid staff. 
Management who used to be in HR actually sexually harassed employees without any repercussions even with ALL of senior leadership knowing about it.
Firing managers, senior leaderships, and VPs is seen as a weakness so they will keep people around who are clearly unqualified just to save face. 
Being a "cool place to work" invites inappropriate behavior that is brushed off as being "fun" or "hip" yet they push unbias training down everyones throat and make it mandatory that you show up. It's not helpful and all it does is push people who were already afraid of speaking up further into their corners.

headline: Great place
pros: Free lunch and snacks every day, and the people are just amazing.
cons: Not sure what a lot of people do across the office, which can be hard at times.

headline: Not the best place to work for anymore :(
pros:
- great perks like free lunches, stocked kitchen, events
- great benefits
- open space environment
cons:
- the culture used to be top-notch, now that the company has grown a lot and still keeps growing, the culture is slipping away. I've read other reviews about Thumbtack too especially the negative ones and they're all on point. They say that they're not micromanaging you but the truth is they are. They use positive-scripting to "keep the culture"  but they're not really doing a great job. 
- when it comes to promotion, it's also who you know and not what you know. 
- people that are personally struggling don't get much support from the management and the company although that WAS their intention. It used to be an employee-centered company too, but now they're just about numbers and how to make the company bigger. 
- I used to brag about Thumbtack but now I would not even recommend it to anyone anymore because of all the changes
- not much career growth. They used to say that since it's a start-up company, there are tons of growth opportunity, everything has been filled in I guess so you're staying where you're at now.

headline: Best places to work
pros: catered lunches every day- given a mac book for work and personal use while employed for Thumbtack.- very career development focused- lots of growth opportunities
cons: not much management growth- once at a manager level you have reached a ceiling.

headline: Once in a lifetime work opportunity
pros:
Thumbtack is truly a unique company. Radical transparency, smart and humble colleagues, huge opportunity, fast growth, and a clear vision make Thumbtack an amazing place to work.

On top of that, Thumbtack is taking its thriving marketplace and taking a huge swing at a radically improved experience for local services. Trust me when I say this is a once in a lifetime work opportunity. 

I would happily recommend Thumbtack to any great employee who wants to love their work and make a huge difference.
cons: Building something new and different is not easy. If you are not comfortable with ambiguity and moving quickly, you will likely find yourself unhappy at Thumbtack in its current stage.

headline: Used to be a great place to work at.
pros: Thumbtack has some amazing people still working there. You get catered lunch, free snacks, and awesome events are planned. The product Thumbtack is working on will change the services market, if they don't continue on this horrible path they are on.
cons:
Micromanagers, bosses instead of leaders, metrics that are hard to obtain, constantly being told you're paid more than you're worth, constant changes that don't make any sense.

The changes that are made on a weekly basis just anger professionals we work with and they feel like Thumbtack is just in it for the money, which is it seeming like it more and more everyday. When you bring up feedback, you think they care about it, but they don't do much to implement it. We have 2 offices, and the office in SF is not in tune with SLC, so they make changes that WE know are going to anger customers, and they are surprised when they get negative feedback. 

TT used to brag about transparency and how much they valued their employees, now they only care about numbers and you can end up getting fired in a matter of weeks because of their high metrics. 

Lots of politics, if you're a brown noser, you will get special projects to work on and not have to work as hard as everyone else. 

You are only important to Thumbtack as long as you are performing, if you have a tough week, you will get into a bad groove and it's hard to recover.

Some "leaders" take it upon themselves to target employees and try to get them fired for bringing up issues to upper management or hr. 

The good people are realizing that it's better to leave then stay and deal with all the garbage going on so tenured employees are dropping like flies.

headline: Great Company (if you're at HQ)
pros:
-Nice perks (standard startup stuff like snacks in kitchen) 
-Proximity to public transportation
-Great service. It really taps into an important market, small businesses
-  Laid back culture
- A few very smart and qualified people sent over by PE backers
cons: - This is specific to the Utah office. It's essentially a call center. They try to slice it and dice it in different ways, but it's a call center.  Yes, it's a nice office, it's much better than a traditional call center job. But if you are looking for exciting work to do, work close to the product, decision makers, development, etc... You will be disappointed in Utah.  My recruiter did an amazing job making me think that they actually did more than just call center operations.

headline: Amazing growth, business problems, and team
pros:
I've personally grown much faster than I expected. I've learned as much about software engineering as I have about product decision-making, analytics, and project management—all as a new-grad hire.

Almost everyone here is exceptionally helpful and cooperative. The company is intensely mission-driven and people are well-aligned with the company's vision.

People here are smart. With few exceptions, I am impressed by the caliber of team members here and the lengths they go to not only understand our customers, product, and market.

There is immense company growth potential. We are years ahead of even our biggest competitors in a market that, in the US alone, is worth $700 billion annually. There are few other tech companies that can even claim to have that much potential for growth—let alone a strong chance at realizing that potential.

Upper management is excellent. I rarely question the decisions made by executives about our team and our product because they are accessible, transparent about their reasoning, and deeply concerned with data-driven decision-making. At the same time, they seem to balance these traits with well-honed intuitions about how to make step changes in the product that take us in the right direction.
cons:
While the company has been receptive to feedback about career growth, it still has room for improvement. I realize catering to people's career growth needs is often in tension with team agility and bureaucracy minimization, but I think Thumbtack is capable of finding a better balance.

Given our ambitions, we need to grow our team more quickly than we currently are, without resorting to the pell-mell of hiring that was 2016. I think a crucial part of this will be polishing our brand and doing better at publicizing the great work we're doing here.

headline: Smart people, super exciting mission, great culture
pros:
- People are really smart, accomplished, and well meaning (if young)
- Great culture: fun, respectful, transparent culture
- Huge market and vision for the company: no lack of desire to change the world
- Accessible leadership
cons: - Tons of growth and change can be somewhat chaotic and hard to keep up

headline: There's more than one way to skin a cat
pros: Great free lunches , great life skills training
cons: Horrible managers. Chained to a phone.

headline: Recruiter
pros: Thumbtack has an amazing Culture, and they really value their employees.
cons: I can't think of any cons, because Thumbtack is the best company to work for.

headline: Very Agile
pros: Working with Mikan, by far is the best!
cons: Micromanagement in the Philippines team and agility of the business. People come and go only because the only stable job in Thumbtack Philippines is the customer service team.

headline: Amazing company to work for!
pros: Very nice and smart people.
cons: Tough to make horizontal movement within the company.

headline: Politics & Great Food
pros:
- Food is really amazing
- Coworkers have become close friends, overall good people
- Busy, no lulls
- Weekly all hands - gives insight to business health for all levels of employees
- Good benefit with unlimited PTO, but it's often frowned upon when using
- Above market salaries
cons:
- The company struggled with their goal statement -- it's tough to feel empowered when the main objective is revenue, nothing bigger
- No 401k matching
- Upper levels are heavy on politics; nepotism over meritocracy 
- Be careful who you talk to. Even HR is not confidential 
- Not interested in cultivating employees; easier to burn and turn over
- On call 24/7 - would be working nights and weekends
- Focused on short-term success, not investing in long-term (ROI > Brand)

headline: Good people, comfortable work environment, interesting product
pros: Company is a good stage. Not so new that there's constant startup chaos but not so established that you can't make a difference in how things are built. Lots of care taken in hiring to find both skill and culture fit.
cons: Legacy code annoying to deal with at times but that's being addressed.

headline: Exceptional Culture + Exciting Vision and Potential
pros: Let's start with the easy stuff: amazing lunches and snacks served daily, great office space, excellent activities and spirit days, awesome swag. But that's really just the surface layer. If you go deeper, you find the office culture is friendly and open, nearly all members of management at all levels are motivated sincerely to help people succeed and grow, and the company values and product vision are compelling. I've worked with many different companies in varying capacities, and I've rarely seen a company with so many positives. Summary: It's an exceptional place to work, and the product has incredible potential.
cons: This may sound like I'm glossing over things, but there really aren't any major cons compared to other companies in similar spaces. Like all things, you'll get out of out what you put into it, and if your style is to hide out or get by on minimum effort, this probably won't be a good fit for you. Also, the pace Thumbtack moves (fast!) isn't for everyone.

headline: One of the best startups
pros:
* Front seat in changing the local service marketplace, helping both professionals and customers to become successful,  great potential to grow
* Working with mix experience levels people, learning from each other, smart and humble, from individual contributor all the way to founders.
* Data driven and reasonable in almost all aspects, huge #loveit
cons: not many, might be good to include 401k matching

headline: Great job
pros: They genuinely care about each of their employees and offer a good wage for the area
cons: The culture feels like a high school click sometimes and its very hard to move up.

headline: Great place for female engineers
pros:
Perks are good, work is great, the people are AWESOME.
Great values, that aren't just talked about, these seep through the organization.
One of the core values is Make Each Other Better.  I've found it easy to learn, share and grow technically. Having a common goal and clear shared vision help integrate the team. I've worked at multiple companies and I value the transparency at Thumbtack. Join Us!
cons: Middle management is super new and learning the ropes.  Employee median age is likely below 30's.

headline: One of the Best Places to Work in SF Bay Area
pros:
- Amazing perks: top culinary team, incredible health benefits, quarterly offsites and all-company kick-offs, happy hours, workshops to help you improve your skills like public speaking and giving constructive feedback. Our founders are dedicated to investing in the people here and making sure we have the tools to do well. It's unlike anything I've seen before.
-Awesome people: the team is committed to recruiting and hiring top talent so we can get to the next level of where we want to be while maintaining an amazing culture. 
- Inspiring mission: we help hundreds of thousands of professionals find customers and work every day. It's amazing to hear stories of how we've changed people's lives. Makes you excited to get out of bed everyday and come to work.
cons: We're growing quickly and it feels like there are a lot of new faces.

headline: Challenging but exciting job
pros:
As a software engineer:
1. you have a lot of responsibility, your work will have big impact
2. you can learn different technology, almost everyone works full stack here
3. you have opportunity to work with really smart, insightful people, technical and non-technical
cons:
1. you will be juggling multiple tasks and it is overwhelming sometimes
2. bigger scope sometimes also means less depth

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
I love coming to work here every day.  We are helping real customers with important life projects while helping small businesses nationwide grow.  That mission and that impact creates a really positive baseline for everyone here.

In addition, my colleagues are nearly uniformly friendly, warm, and smart.  Meetings are collegial, even when there is disagreement.  Hours and work-life-balance are very manageable, even when you have a family as I do.  And, because we are growing fast, there are tons of opportunities to grow with the company and learn new things all along the way.
cons: I think we just have the ordinary downsides that come with scaling a company quickly, like sometimes slightly unclear decision-making frameworks.  That said, the collegial atmosphere makes even these minor cons easy to work around and within.  Plus the leadership team is acutely aware of the challenges that come with growth and constantly working to address them.

headline: Great if you don't work in product
pros: Overall company culture is very fun and loving. You'll meet smart, interesting, and fun people. It feels like family. The meals are top rated. Thumbtack leadership makes an effort to better itself and the company. You'll actually see exec involved and participating in the office. Since there's a lot of build and do, you'll get the opportunity to work on ground breaking projects.
cons: No 401k matching. Worklife balance isn't great, you can expect Slack and email notifications through the night and weekend. The engineering, product, and design cultures aren't well aligned. Engineering tends to get highest precedent. The product development process is still in progress. The day to day working experience is intense because of the EPD culture of urgency and many meetings.  Decision making at every stage of product is heavily dependent on committee decisions amongst product management.  There is no career development framework or explicit role definition.  Although the culture values transparency, management often lacks transparency.  Not enough headcount.

headline: Good Company Culture
pros:
• The culture and people who work there are nothing short of amazing. Everyone gets along with each other and it feels like family. No matter your religious beliefs, your interests, your political views, everyone accepts everyone for who they truly are. It's a rare find.
• Fast paced company that is constantly growing and changing. You will hardly ever be bored. 
• Company perks are great. They really do take care of their people.
cons:
• The word "transparent" is a value of the company and it use to be apart of the culture, which was awesome. In the last year, there were a lot of secrets and things seemed pretty shady. It's really unfortunate because many have stopped trusting their leaders.
• The communication between departments is horrendous. Nobody knows what anyone else is doing, major changes are made without anyone's opinion, and some people just do whatever they want to and don't tell anyone.

headline: Patience not a virtue at Thumbtack
pros: Engineers are always are willing and able to help with whatever problems you may have in getting stuff done.  The people who work with you are excellent.
cons: Unfortunately, the same cannot be said of engineering managers.  You are kept on a very short leash, and they will consider you persona non grata if you don't adjust quickly.

headline: Great People Unleashing Great Potential
pros:
I have been working at Thumbtack for a year and am very happy with the choice I made in joining Thumbtack!

- Very user (pro and consumer) focused
- Really humble co-workers
- Open and honest culture
- High bar for shipping features, designing architecture and investing in infrastructure
- Data driven
- Not afraid to move fast
- Starts with the assumption that everyone is a rockstar and given very high impact projects (with mentorship and guidance along the way)
- Very good growth opportunities
- Competitive compensation and benefits
cons:
- Still trying to figure out processes that work best, allowing us to move fast and make the right decisions at the same time
- Hopefully we can maintain the culture and potential of Thumbtack even as we are in this high growth phase
- Although, we are data driven, we still haven't explored the full potential of the experimentation techniques and tools out there. We should invest more in those tools, especially as our product becomes more sophisticated

headline: Great people, Great Mission!
pros: There are too many-- however, our product and the people are what make this place so great! Also, we get to empower local professionals to focus more on their work/craft/vocation, and we've made them over $1,000,000,000 (and rising). At the end of the day, I know I'm helping professionals and families put food on the table.
cons: Everyone is smiling too much for a Monday at 8am, give me 10 minutes to wake up my positive attitude :). I honestly can't think of any non-trivial cons.

headline: You have to want it!
pros: They pay relatively well, and the benefits package is tremendous.
cons: It is exceedingly difficult to get hired full time at Thumbtack, so once you do get the job, be advised: The expectation of you will be not only to define your own role, but to exceed beyond your own set expectations of yourself. That is the baseline for continued employment at this company. You must constantly innovate, push ideas forward, generate solutions, and think of problems that have not yet arisen and solve them. If you simply go about your day doing the duties written in your job description, it will not be enough. You have to be a Thumbtack true believer, or you will not make it for very long. You can imagine what this means for your work-life balance.

headline: Great company in Salt Lake!
pros: Amazing company mission and culture
cons: Not a lot of room from growth

headline: The Best Company In the World
pros:
Thumbtack truly cares about its employees at every level. You can't find a company that cards all the way down to the bottom like this one does. 

Very fair pay and compensation. I think some people might take for granted what they get from this company because they go above and beyond compared to what you can get elsewhere. They treat CS like Tech employees. 

A lot of available trainings to improve your skills in the workplace.
cons: There are is a click vibe with the Marketplace Integrity team. They very much keep to themselves and honestly could do better at being a part of the team.

headline: Great experience! Definitely recommend.
pros:
- Amazing team with a strong mission and vision. 
- Great people managers that focus on your growth and development. 
- You can tell people care deeply about our pros and customers.
- Decisions are data-driven. 

I've been recommending Thumbtack to friends! Great company, excited for the future.
cons: Nothing major here. Like with most companies that are scaling, we need to find the right balance and formats for communicating broadly with other teams for transparency, but also cut down on meetings and information so we can stay focused on our output/impact.

headline: Truly one of the "Best Places to Work 2017"
pros:

- Very open to making things better
- Low ego colleagues

headline: Awesome Company
pros: Brilliant people, cool perks, down-to-earth CEOs. Exciting plans for the future. Fantastic culture. It's a dynamic company and they're always looking for ways to improve.
cons: None so far. Will update if I come up with any.

headline: Best company I've ever worked for

- Relevant product in a large market
- Great work/life balance

- Positive company culture with tons of smart people
- Transparent decision making

headline: LOVED this place
pros: Amazing culture and work environment. Even better benefits.
cons: None that I can even think of.

headline: Best in Utah
